labelLink.label: Interest in closely held corporation.
Garnishment Payable
Real Estate, Non Business
The total amount due within more than 12 months, or the operating cycle if longer, on all notes payable related to purchases of equipment.
Advances that were paid out to stockholders and are not expected to be earned, and therefore must be written off.
Amounts due but not yet received from payroll taxes, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).

The right-of-use asset is a lessee's right to use an asset over the life of a lease. The asset is calculated as the initial amount of the lease liability, plus any lease payments made to the lessor before the lease commencement date, plus any initial direct costs incurred, minus any lease incentives received.
Amount of insurance policy dividends.
Amount before accumulated depreciation of computers used in the normal conduct of business to produce goods and services and not intended for resale.
Joint Venture Liability, Company Portion

Minority interest in affiliates of the company, which is the total of all stockholders' equity (deficit) items, net of receivables from officers, directors, owners, and affiliates of the entity which is directly or indirectly attributable to that ownership interest in subsidiary equity which is not attributable to the parent (that is, noncontrolling interest, previously referred to as minority interest).
Natural Resources
Accounts Payable Subcontractor
Amount of expense for occupancy and utilities.
Advances, Written Off
Amount of expense for officer bonuses.
Amount of deferred mortgage payments.
Accounts Receivable, Non Litigation Disputes, Noncurrent
The portion of notes receivable due from officers which is to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date.
Personal Property
Joint Checks Payable
Accounts Receivable, Stock Subscription, Noncurrent
Gravel Pit
Revenue from Joint Venture
The portion of notes receivable due from affiliates which is to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date.
Deposits of federal taxes, for example for payroll taxes.
Amount of advance payments due from an entity in which the reporting entity shares joint control with another party or group, due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Amount of workers compensation insurance that is owed.
A long-term asset account that reports the value of a company's airplanes on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Advances Due from Joint Ventures
Amount after tax of income (loss) from continuing operations including portion attributable to the noncontrolling interest, and before bonuses.
Amount of cost attributed to the subcontractor.
Joint Venture, Contributed Capital
Deferred Expenses
Amount of union benefits that have been accrued but not yet paid.
Vehicles
Value of U.S. treasury bills held on the balance sheet for more than one year.

Sum of the carrying values as of the balance sheet date of obligations incurred through that date and due after one year (or beyond the operating cycle if longer), including liabilities for compensation costs, fringe benefits other than pension and postretirement obligations, rent, contractual rights and obligations, and statutory obligations.
Notes Payable to Officers, Noncurrent
Carrying amount of the personal property held.

Equity adjustments are salary changes outside of the normal salary programs (promotions, reclassifications, merits, etc.) to remedy salary issues such as external pressure in high demand areas, internal salary compression, and/or retention considerations.
Patents
Prepaid Income Taxes, Noncurrent
Amounts due from the partnership, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
The portion of notes receivable due from affiliates which is to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date.
Amount of deposit made for workers compensation insurance.
Non Compete Covenant
Cost, Subcontractor
Tenant deposits that must be paid back.

Debt security, in which the authorized issuer owes the holder a debt and is obliged to repay the principal and interest (the coupon), which are held instead of retainage. Retainage is a portion of the agreed upon contract price deliberately withheld until the work is substantially complete to assure that contractor or subcontractor will satisfy its obligations and complete a construction project.
The portion of notes receivable due from the partnership which is to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date.

Amount, after unamortized (discount) premium and debt issuance costs, of long-term debt, classified as current. Includes, but not limited to, notes payable, bonds payable, debentures, mortgage loans and commercial paper. Excludes capital lease obligations.
Accruals, Noncurrent
Amount before accumulated depreciation of communication equipment used in the normal conduct of business to produce goods and services and not intended for resale.

A long-term asset account that reports the value of a company's transportation equipment on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Workers Compensation Insurance Deposit
Contracts Liabilities Account
The value of all securities held.
Amount of natural resources held.
Broker Margin Account
Accounts Receivable, Earned Estimates, Noncurrent
Notes Receivable Mortgage, Current
Amounts to be paid to an entity in which the reporting entity shares joint control with another party or group, due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Notes Receivable Other, Current
Amount of revenue recognized from joint venture activities.
Accounts Receivable, Partner, Noncurrent
Trucks
Amounts due but not yet received from partners, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Amount of long-term accruals on the balance sheet.
Contract Cost, Deferred Change Order, Amount
Capitalized Leases
Carrying value on the balance sheet of joint venture liabilities held for longer than one year.
Royalties
Long-term Debt, Current Maturities
Asphalt Plants
Equity Not Otherwise Classified
Amounts due but not yet received from service contracts, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Accounts Payable and Accrued Liabilities, Noncurrent
Accounts Receivable, Insurance Claims, Noncurrent
Document and Entity [Abstract]
Amount of deferred annuity which is a contract that provides a stream of payments beginning at a future date.
A long-term asset account that reports the value of a company's farm on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Amount of expenses attributed to estimating and prospecting new jobs.
Communication Equipment
Investment in Development or Land
Amounts due from officers of the company, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Amount of equity held in securities.

Amount of contract change cost which is a contractor’s right to additional time and/or compensation for work performed outside the scope of the original contract, and which is expected to be recovered.

Value of chattel mortgage payable. Chattel mortgage is a legal term used to describe a loan arrangement in which an item of movable personal property is used as security for the loan. The movable property, or chattel, guarantees the loan in this type of mortgage. This differs from a conventional mortgage in which the loan is secured by a lien on real property.
The amount of notes payable to shareholders that have not been repaid and which are classified as current liabilities because the amounts are due within one year of the balance sheet date.
Accounts Receivable, Owner, Noncurrent
Amounts due from owners or owners with a beneficial interest of more than 10 percent of the voting interests, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Amount of insurance refunds.
Value carried on the balance sheet for a company's 401(k) plan, which is the tax-qualified, defined-contribution pension account defined in subsection 401(k) of the Internal Revenue Code.
Amount of asset related to consideration paid in advance for income taxes that provide economic benefits within a future period of one year or the normal operating cycle, if longer.
Notes Payable Related Parties, Current
Contracts Assets Account
Money Market Funds, at Carrying Value, Noncurrent
Amounts due to recorded owners or owners with a beneficial interest of more than 10 percent of the voting interests which are due after one year (or one business cycle).
Annuities

Carrying value on the balance sheet of retainage payable to contractors for contracts which are uncompleted. Retainage is a portion of the agreed upon contract price deliberately withheld until the work is substantially complete to assure that contractor or subcontractor will satisfy its obligations and complete a construction project.
The portion of notes receivable due from employees which is to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date.
Accounts Receivable, Management Fees, Noncurrent
Amounts due from the parent company, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Amount of expense for discretionary bonuses.
Yard and Yard Improvements
Notes Receivable from Employee Stock Option Plans, Noncurrent

A long-term asset account that reports the value of a company's yard and yard improvements on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
The portion of notes receivable due from mortgage payments which is to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date.
Contract Change Order
Amount of corporate stock.
Corporate Stock

Carrying amount of loans that have been capitalized. Loan capitalization occurs when accrued and unpaid interest is added to the principal. For a loan to be capitalized, it must have interest that accrues during a time when the borrower is not making any payments, for example, student loans.
Investment in Subsidiaries
Notes Payable to Shareholders, Noncurrent
Workers Compensation Insurance Owed
Information about the document and the entity.

Amount of receivable reflecting the cost incurred on uncompleted contracts in excess of related billings which is expected to be collected within one year or the normal operating cycle, if longer. Amount also includes Retainage Receivables which has not been released.
Amount of investment in marketable security, classified as noncurrent that have been pledged.
Capitalized Expenses

A long-term asset account that reports the value of a company's gravel pit or rights to a gravel pit on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Plant and Buildings
Notes Receivable from Stockholders, Noncurrent
Demand Notes
Accounts Receivable, Trade, Noncurrent
Amounts due but not yet received, for insurance claims, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle.)
Cost of Sales, Joint Venture
Equity in Affiliates
Amount of equity held in affiliates.
Notes Payable Parent, Current
Accounts Receivable, Life Insurance, Noncurrent
Amount of asset related to consideration paid in advance for state taxes that provide economic benefits within a future period of one year or the normal operating cycle, if longer.
Notes Payable for Equipment, Noncurrent
Long-term liabilities of subsidiaries that are carried on the balance sheet.
Non Marketable Securities, Noncurrent
Salary and other types of compensation for officers of the company and shareholders.
Interest in real estate partnership.
Deferred Interest
Amounts due but not yet received for intercompany payments, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle.)
Marketable Securities Pledged
Amounts due from subsidiaries, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Improvements Not Elsewhere Classified
Unamortized Interest
Notes Receivable from Partnership, Noncurrent
Payment for club fees.
The total amount due within more than 12 months, or the operating cycle if longer, on all notes payable related to a buyout.
Restricted Certificates of Deposit, at Carrying Value
Concrete Forms
Officer Bonuses
Amount of asset related to consideration paid in advance for rent that provides economic benefits within a future period of one year or the normal operating cycle, if longer.
Amounts due but not yet received from subsidiaries, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Due from Partnership, Noncurrent
Amount of demand notes which are loans with no fixed term or repayment schedule, which can be recalled upon the lender's request, assuming the notice required by the provisions of the loan are met.
Amounts due but not yet received, for disputes or litigation, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle.)
S Corp Distribution Payable, Current
Transportation Equipment
Minority Interest, Affiliate
Notes and Loans Payable, Current
Bonds in Lieu of Retainage
Carrying amount of equipment, not otherwise classified.
Amount of long-term notes classified as other, payable within one year or the normal operating cycle, if longer.
Amount representing mutual funds carried on the balance sheet.
Capitalized Organizational Costs
The portion of notes receivable due from unrelated parties which is to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date.
The total amount due within more than 12 months, or the operating cycle if longer, on all notes payable to officers.
Accounts Receivable, Construction Claims, Noncurrent
A long-term asset account that reports the value of a company's automobiles on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Amounts due but not yet received from stock subscriptions, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
A long-term asset account that reports the value of a company's processing plants on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Amount of cash and cash equivalents unrestricted as to withdrawal or usage, classified as noncurrent.
A long-term asset account that reports the value of a company's marine equipment on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Processing Plants
Investment and Advances to Affiliates
Amounts due to subcontractor for completion of contracted work.
Pledged Certificates of Deposit, at Carrying Value
Cash Payroll
Notes Payable for Buyout, Noncurrent
Accounts Receivable, Service Contracts, Noncurrent
The amount of notes payable to affiliates that have not been repaid and which are classified as current liabilities because the amounts are due within one year of the balance sheet date.

Noncurrent portion of investment in short-term money-market instruments (such as commercial paper, banker's acceptances, repurchase agreements, government securities, certificates of deposit, and so forth) which are highly liquid (that is, readily convertible to known amounts of cash) and so near their maturity that they present an insignificant risk of changes in value because of changes in interest rates. Generally, only investments with original maturities of three months or less qualify as cash equivalents by definition. Original maturity means an original maturity to the entity holding the investment. For example, both a three-month US Treasury bill and a three-year Treasury note purchased three months from maturity qualify as cash equivalents. However, a Treasury note purchased three-years ago does not become a cash equivalent when its remaining maturity is three months.
Amounts due but not yet received from parent company, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Amounts due but not yet received from completed contracts, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Mutual Funds
Accounts Receivable, Accumulated Amortization, Noncurrent
Accounts Receivable, Payroll Tax, Noncurrent
A long-term asset account that reports the value of a company's warehouse on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Insurance Dividend
Notes Receivable Stockholders, Current
Amount of interest that has not been amortized.
Amount of joint checks payable. Joint checks are checks made out to two payees — most often a subcontractor and the subcontractor's supplier.
Amounts due but not yet received from unbilled amounts related to contracts, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).

Amount of deferred expense which is a cost that has already been incurred, but which has not yet been consumed. The cost is recorded as an asset until such time as the underlying goods or services are consumed; at that point, the cost is charged to expense.
Amounts due but not yet received from payroll taxes, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Amount before accumulated depreciation of concrete forms used in the normal conduct of business to produce goods and services and not intended for resale.
Bonds
Amounts due from owners or owners with a beneficial interest of more than 10 percent of the voting interests or officers of the company, which are usually due within 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Value of expenses that will be reimbursed.
Notes Payable Equipment, Current
Accounts Receivable, Advances to Subcontractors, Noncurrent
Long Term Joint Venture Liabilities
Amount of cost incurred on construction contract for deferred change order, claim, or similar item subject to uncertainty.

Amount of physical assets used in the normal conduct of business to produce goods and services and not intended for resale. Examples include, but are not limited to, buildings (physical plant), machinery and equipment, office equipment, and furniture and fixtures. Does not include property.

The amount of notes payable that are S Corp distributions that have not been repaid and which are classified as noncurrent liabilities because the amounts are due in more than one year of the balance sheet date.
Amounts due from officers of the company, which are usually due within 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
The portion of notes receivable on mortgages which is to be received within one year of the balance sheet date.
Advances, Joint Venture
Insurance Claim Receivable
Notes Receivable Affiliate, Noncurrent
Investments in Joint Ventures, Current
Marine Equipment
Treasury Bills
Amount of certificates of deposit that are pledged to a secure party, that are classified as noncurrent.
Equity in Joint Ventures
Due from Other Related Parties, Noncurrent
Value of U.S. treasury bonds held on the balance sheet for more than one year.
Expenses incurred for training.
Amount of investment in subsidiaries.
Amounts due for a construction claim but not yet received, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Amount of investment in development or land.
Amount of deferred construction costs.
Chattel Mortgage Payable
A long-term asset account that reports the value of a company's horses on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Amount representing funds spent on joint venture agreements, within a period of one year.
Notes Receivable from Mortgage Payments, Noncurrent
Accounts Receivable, Litigation or Disputes, Noncurrent
Amount of accounts payable to subsidiaries, due after one year or beyond the normal operating cycle, if longer.
Investment In Partnerships
Training Expense
Cost of Occupancy and Utilities
Retainage, Uncompleted Contracts
Estimating and Prospecting Job Expense
Autos
Due from Parent, Noncurrent
Warehouse
Long Term Liabilities, Subsidiaries
The portion of notes receivable due from subsidiaries which is to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date.
Officer and Shareholder Compensation
Insurance Deposit
Represents real estate held for non-business purposes.
Amounts due but not yet received from owner, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
A long-term asset account that reports the value of asphalt plants on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Other Notes Payable, Current
Notes Receivable from Unrelated Parties, Noncurrent
Amount receivable from related parties classified as other, due after one year or the normal operating cycle, if longer.

Amount of deferred interest which is the amount of interest added to the principal balance of a loan when the contractual terms of the loan allow for a scheduled payment to be made that is less than the interest due.
Amounts due but not yet received from tax refunds including federal and other refunds, not including state tax refunds, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Deferred Annuity
Livestock
Notes Receivable from Employees, Noncurrent
Amount of certificates of deposit that are restricted as to withdrawal or usage, classified as noncurrent.
Amounts due but not yet received from rental income which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Insurance claims that have not yet been received and are classified as long-term.
Club Fee Payment
Securities
Amounts due but not yet received, from life insurance, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle.)
Amounts due but not yet received, from Federal Tax Refunds, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle.)
Boat
Accounts Receivable, Intercompany, Noncurrent

Amounts due but not yet received from trade, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle). Trade receivables are amounts billed by a business to its customers when it delivers goods or services to them in the ordinary course of business.
Deferred Construction Costs
Interest in Real Estate Partnership
Amounts due for earned estimates but not yet received, which are due within 1 year (or 1 business cycle).

The amount of notes payable that are S Corp distributions that have not been repaid and which are classified as current liabilities because the amounts are due within one year of the balance sheet date.
Accounts Receivable, Earned Estimates, Current
Accounts Receivable, Tax Refund, Noncurrent
Interest in Closely Held Corporation
Treasury Notes
Notes Payable Shareholders, Current
Prepaid State Taxes, Noncurrent
Amounts due for earned estimates which are revenues on uncompleted projects, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Income (Loss) Before Bonuses and Provision for Income Taxes
Airplane
Accounts Receivable, Parent, Noncurrent
Amounts due but not yet received for mortgage payments, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
A long-term asset account that reports the value of a company's boats on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Amount before accumulated depreciation of improvements not classified as building, land or leasehold.
Retainage, Completed Contracts
A long-term asset account that reports the value of asphalt plants on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Amount of investment in and advances to affiliates.
Interest in Joint Venture
Accounts Receivable, Unbilled, Noncurrent
Accounts Receivable, Insurance Dividends, Noncurrent
Notes Receivable Officer, Current
Notes Receivable from Other, Noncurrent
Amounts due but not yet received for management fees, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).

A long-term asset account that reports the value of automobiles, trucks, and other vehicles on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Amounts due but not yet received from payroll taxes, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Amount for accounts payable of retainage that reflects the amount billed to customers under long-term contracts or programs that have been withheld because of retainage provisions in a contract.
Federal Tax Deposit
Capitalized Loans
Notes Payable Affiliates, Current
Notes Receivable from Lessor, Noncurrent
Amounts due for insurance dividends but not yet received, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle.)
Due from Stockholders, Noncurrent
The portion of notes receivable due from officers which is to be received within one year of the balance sheet date.
Notes Receivable from Officers, Noncurrent
Capital Lease Equipment
Amount that represents the value of long-term annuities.

Carrying value on the balance sheet of retainage payable to contractors for contracts which are completed. Retainage is a portion of the agreed upon contract price deliberately withheld until the work is substantially complete to assure that contractor or subcontractor will satisfy its obligations and complete a construction project.
Farm
Accounts Receivable, Completed Contracts, Noncurrent
Accounts Payable Retainage
Deferred Mortgage Payments
Unrestricted Cash and Cash Equivalents, Noncurrent
Amount of equity held in joint ventures.
Equipment Other
Amount before accumulated depreciation of construction equipment used in the normal conduct of business to produce goods and services and not intended for resale.
Contributed capital of the joint venture, which is the cash and other assets that shareholders have given a company in exchange for stock.
Amount of investment in and advances to limited liability companies.
Due from Officers, Current
Accrued Union Benefits
Equity Adjustments
The portion of notes receivable from employee stock option plans (ESOP), which is to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date.
Amount representing the value of the joint venture.

The portion of notes receivable due from trade which is to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date. Trade receivables are amounts billed by a business to its customers when it delivers goods or services to them in the ordinary course of business.
A long-term asset account that reports the value of a company's trucks on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Accounts Receivable, Subsidiary, Noncurrent
Amount carried on the balance sheet to recognize the share of liability of a joint venture. Can also be used when there is negative equity and there needs to be a corresponding liability recorded.
Due from Officers, Noncurrent
The amount of ownership interest not otherwise classified.

Liability attributable to (i) billings in excess of costs under the percentage of completion contract accounting method representing the difference between contractually invoiced amounts (billings) and revenue recognized based, for example, on costs incurred to estimated total costs at period end or (ii) contractually invoiced amounts (billings) in excess of costs incurred and accumulated under the completed contract accounting method that are expected to be realized within one year or one operating cycle, whichever is longer, from the reporting date. Amount also includes Retainage Receivables which has not been released.
Amount of equity held in land.
The value of royalties on the balance sheet.
The portion of notes receivable due from stockholders which is to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date.
Accounts Receivable, Accumulated Depletion, Noncurrent
Amount before accumulated depreciation of leased computers used in the normal conduct of business to produce goods and services.
Notes Receivable Trade, Noncurrent
Accounts Receivable, Stockholders, Noncurrent
Deferred Losses
The portion of notes receivable due from other organizations not otherwise classified which is to be received within one year of the balance sheet date.
Due from Stockholders, Current

Capitalized costs are expenses that are added to the cost basis of a fixed asset on a company's balance sheet. Capitalized costs are incurred when building or financing fixed assets. Capitalized costs are not expensed in the period they were incurred but recognized over a period of time via depreciation or amortization.
A long-term asset account that reports the value of bonds on a company's balance sheet.
Amounts due but not yet received from payroll taxes, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Notes Receivable from Subsidiaries, Noncurrent
Reimbursable Expenses
Value of non-compete covenants which are identifiable intangible assets.
Amount of insurance deposit.
401(k) Plan
The amount of notes payable to parents that have not been repaid and which are classified as current liabilities because the amounts are due within one year of the balance sheet date.
Cattle
Leased Computers
Equity in Land
Amount of cash and cash equivalents set aside for payroll.
Unearned advances that must be repaid.
Amount of investment in partnerships.
Accounts Payable, Subsidiaries, Noncurrent
Investment and Advances to Limited Liability Companies
Value of broker margin accounts which are accounts offered by brokerage firms that allows investors to borrow money to buy securities.
The portion of notes receivable due from affiliates which is to be received within one year of the balance sheet date.
Amount representing the value of patents owned by the company that appears on the balance sheet.
Accounts Receivable, Mortgage, Noncurrent
The portion of notes receivable due from stockholders which is to be received within one year of the balance sheet date.
Insurance Refund
Construction Equipment
Accounts Receivable, Rental Income, Noncurrent
Tenant Deposits
The portion of notes receivable due from parent which is to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date.
Amounts due but not yet received from stockholders, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Unearned Advances
Amounts due for non-litigation disputes that but not yet received, which are usually due after 1 year (or 1 business cycle).
Discretionary Bonus Expense
Carrying amount of organizational costs that have been capitalized.
Horses
A long-term asset account that reports the value of a company's livestock on the balance sheet. The account is reported under the balance sheet classification property, plant, and equipment.
Notes Receivable from Parent, Noncurrent
Right of Use Asset
The amount of notes payable to related parties that have not been repaid and which are classified as current liabilities because the amounts are due within one year of the balance sheet date.
Notes Receivable Affiliate, Current

Carrying amount of capital leases which are contracts entitling a renter to the temporary use of an asset, and such a lease has the economic characteristics of asset ownership for accounting purposes. The capital lease requires a renter to book assets and liabilities associated with the lease if the rental contract meets specific requirements. A capital lease is considered a purchase of an asset
Amount of deferred losses.
This current liability account reports the amount a company must remit to a court or other agencies for amounts withheld from its employees' salaries and wages.
The portion of notes receivable due from other which is to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date.
Equity in Securities
The amount of notes payable for equipment purchases that have not been repaid and which are classified as current liabilities because the amounts are due within one year of the balance sheet date.
Sum of the carrying values as of the balance sheet date of the portions of all long-term notes and loans payable due within one year or the operating cycle if longer.
Amount of investment in nonmarketable security, classified as noncurrent.
Prepaid Lease
Amount before accumulated depreciation of leased equipment used in the normal conduct of business to produce goods and services.
Accounts Receivable, Federal Tax Refund, Noncurrent
Computers
Cost of sales directly related to joint venture.
S Corp Distribution Payable, Noncurrent
Due from Subsidiaries, Noncurrent
